questions.text: A 26-Year-old primigravida female with onset of labour pain at 8 am in the morning. On P/V examination, she was 2 cm dilated, 20% effaced, and the fetal head station was -1. You as a 3rd year MBBS student asked about partographic representation of the cervical dilatation to the JR posted there. She told you to plot the dilatation at:

options.label: A
options.text: 3cm

options.label: B
options.text: 4cm

options.label: C
options.text: 5 cm

options.label: D
options.text: At the onset of labour

questions.explanation:
Solution:

4cm Graphical recording of cervical dilatation begins at 4 cm. The first vaginal examination is done at the admission and subsequently 4 hourly. As per a recent update; the active stage of labour begins at 6 cm cervical dilatation.

Highyeild:

A partograph is a graphical record of the observations made of a woman in labour. For the progress of labour and salient conditions of the mother and fetus. It was developed and extensively tested by the world health organisation. Objectives: Early detection of abnormal progress of labour. Prevention of prolonged labour. Recognise cephalopelvic disproportion long before obstructed labour. Assist in early decisions on transfer, augmentation, or termination of labour. Increase the quality and regularity of all observations of the mother and fetus. Early recognition of maternal or fetal problems. The partograph can be highly effective in reducing complications from prolonged labour for the mother (postpartum haemorrhage, sepsis, uterine rupture and its sequelae) and for the newborn (death, anoxia).

questions.text: A partogram is considered normal when:

options.label: A
options.text: The cervicograph is to the left of the alert line

options.label: B
options.text: The cervicograph is to the right of the alert line

options.label: C
options.text: The cervicograph is to the right of the action line

options.label: D
options.text: The cervicograph is to the left of the action line

questions.correct_answer: A. The cervicograph is to the left of the alert line
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The cervicograph is to the left of the alert line Options B, C & D are false. The alert line starts at the end of the latent phase (4 cm cervical dilatation) and ends with full dilatation of the cervix (10 cm) in 6 hours (1 cm/h dilatation rate). In normal labour, the cervicograph (cervical dilatation) should be either on the alert line or to the left of it.

Highyeild:

A partograph is a graphical record of the observations made of a woman in labour. For the progress of labour and salient conditions of the mother and fetus. It was developed and extensively tested by the world health organisation.

questions.text: During the delivery of a 25-Year-old primigravida female, the JR asked the intern to take the cervicographic changes and inform if the line goes right to the alert line. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding monitoring and partogram?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal heart rate recorded every 30 minutes.

options.label: B
options.text: Blood pressure is recorded every 2 hours.

options.label: C
options.text: Uterine contractions are to be recorded for 1 hour and intensity and duration are to be recorded according to the colour of the squares.

options.label: D
options.text: Oxytocin to be recorded in dose (mIU/min).

questions.correct_answer: C. Uterine contractions are to be recorded for 1 hour and intensity and duration are to be recorded according to the colour of the squares.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Uterine contractions are to be recorded for 1 hour and intensity and duration are to be recorded according to the colour of the squares. This is the wrong statement as the duration is 30 minutes.

Highyeild:

The components of the partograph which are measured: Patient identification Time — recorded at hourly intervals. Zero time for spontaneous labour is the time of admission in the labour ward and for induced labour is the time of induction Fetal heart rate — recorded every 30 minutes State of membranes and colour of liquor: mark ‘I’ for intact membranes, ‘C’ for clear and ‘M’ for meconium-stained liquor Cervical dilatation and descent of the head Uterine contractions — the squares in the vertical columns are shaded according to duration and intensity. For 30 minutes Drugs and fluids Blood pressure (recorded in a vertical line) every 2 hours and pulse every 30 minutes Oxytocin — concentration in the upper box and dose (m IU/min) in the lower box Urine analysis Temperature record

questions.text: You are attending a 30-Year-old female patient who was admitted in labour at 8 am in the morning in a CHC. On P/V examination, she was 4 cm dilated, 40% effaced, and the fetal station was 2/5. At 4 pm, the cervicograph was right to the action line. Which of the following will be the next course of action?

options.label: A
options.text: Refer to higher centre

options.label: B
options.text: Wait and watch

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate intervention is needed

options.label: D
options.text: This is normal cervical dilatation progress

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Immediate intervention is needed In the given question, the cervicograph was right to the action line. This means that action is needed immediately to save both the mother and the baby.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Refer to the higher centre when the line is right to the alert line. Option: B. Wait and watch need not be done only until the cervicograph plot remains left to the alert line. Option: D. This is not normal cervical dilatation as it has progressed towards the right to the action line.

questions.text: You have your final professional examination. During your practical examination, while attending spotters, one of the spotters is given below. Out of the following options, which one will you mark as incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Fetal heart rate is non-reassuring in the later half of labour.

options.label: B
options.text: The progress of cervical dilatation is not adequate and a later C-section may be required.

options.label: C
options.text: Last uterine contractions notes are not adequate.

options.label: D
options.text: Fetal head station is +3 and is not progressing.

questions.correct_answer: C. Last uterine contractions notes are not adequate.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Last uterine contractions notes are not adequate. In the given partograph the labour is not progressing as the cervical dilatation is at 8 cm for more than 4 hours despite adequate uterine contractions. Hence it is equivalent to active phase arrest.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . The fetal heart rate is dropping and not reassuring as it is below the normal cut-off - around 90 bpm. Option: B . As it is a case of second-phase arrest, hence the cervix dilatation is not adequate and has crossed the action lin e, so prompt intervention is required. Option: D . Fetal head station is +3 and is not progressing as can be seen on the graph.
